name: Past Simple Affirmative - Regular Verbs
description: Form past simple with regular verbs by adding -ed to describe completed past actions

name: Past Simple Spelling Rules
description: Apply spelling rules for -ed endings (double consonants, y to i, silent e)

name: Past Simple - Common Irregular Verbs
description: Use common irregular past forms (went, had, made, took, saw, came, got, etc.)

name: Past Simple Negative
description: Form negatives with didn't + base verb

name: Past Simple Questions
description: Form yes/no questions with Did + subject + base verb

name: Past Simple Wh- Questions
description: Form information questions in past simple (What did you do? Where did you go?)

name: Past Time Expressions
description: Use time expressions for past events (yesterday, last week, ago, in 2020)

name: Was/Were Affirmative
description: Use was/were as past of verb to be for descriptions and states

name: Was/Were Negative and Questions
description: Form negatives (wasn't/weren't) and questions with was/were

name: Present Continuous - Form
description: Form present continuous with am/is/are + verb-ing

name: Present Continuous Spelling -ing
description: Apply spelling rules for -ing (double consonants, drop e, ie to y)

name: Present Continuous - Happening Now
description: Use present continuous for actions happening at the moment of speaking
examples: She is talking on the phone

name: Present Continuous Negative and Questions
description: Form negatives (am not/isn't/aren't + verb-ing) and questions

name: Present Simple vs Continuous
description: Contrast present simple (routines, facts) with present continuous (now, temporary)
examples: I work every day / I'm working now
She lives in London / She's staying in a hotel
They play football / They're playing football

name: Stative Verbs Basic
description: Recognize common stative verbs not used in continuous (like, love, want, need, know, understand)

name: Past Continuous - Form
description: Form past continuous with was/were + verb-ing

name: Past Continuous - Interrupted Action
description: Use past continuous for background action interrupted by past simple (I was walking when it started to rain)
examples: I was watching TV when she called
They were sleeping when the alarm rang
He was driving when it started to rain

name: Narrating Past Events Simple
description: Tell simple stories and describe past experiences using past simple in sequence
examples: Yesterday I woke up at 7. I had breakfast and went to work
Last week I visited my friend. We watched a movie and had dinner

name: Talking About Weekend Activities
description: Describe weekend activities using past simple
examples: I went to the park on Saturday
I stayed at home and relaxed

name: Describing Past Experiences
description: Talk about past experiences, trips, and events with simple details
examples: I visited Paris last year. It was beautiful
I learned to swim when I was ten
I had a great time at the party

name: Could for Past Ability
description: Use could/couldn't to express past ability
examples: I could swim when I was five
Could you speak English as a child?

name: Could for Polite Requests
description: Use could to make polite requests, more formal than can

name: Should for Advice
description: Use should/shouldn't to give advice and recommendations
examples: She shouldn't eat so much sugar

name: Must for Strong Obligation
description: Use must/mustn't to express strong obligation or prohibition

name: Have To for Obligation
description: Use have to/has to/had to for external obligation and necessity
examples: I have to go to work
I had to wait for an hour

name: Don't Have To vs Mustn't
description: Distinguish between don't have to (not necessary) and mustn't (prohibited)
examples: I don't have to work tomorrow

name: Going To for Future Plans
description: Use going to + base verb for plans and intentions
examples: I'm going to visit my friend tomorrow
She's going to start a new job
Are you going to buy a car?

name: Going To for Predictions
description: Use going to for predictions based on present evidence
examples: Look at those clouds! It's going to rain
Be careful! You're going to fall

name: Will for Spontaneous Decisions
description: Use will for decisions made at the moment of speaking
examples: I think I'll go to bed

name: Will for Promises and Offers
description: Use will for promises, offers, and threats

name: Will vs Going To
description: Contrast will (spontaneous, predictions) with going to (plans, evidence-based predictions)
examples: I'll answer the phone (now decision) / I'm going to call him later (plan)
It will rain (opinion) / It's going to rain (dark clouds)

name: Present Continuous for Future Arrangements
description: Use present continuous for fixed future arrangements
examples: She's flying to Paris next week
We're having dinner with them on Friday

name: Comparative Adjectives
description: Form comparatives with -er or more for comparing two things

name: Superlative Adjectives
description: Form superlatives with -est or most for comparing three or more things

name: Irregular Comparatives and Superlatives
description: Use irregular forms (good/better/best, bad/worse/worst, far/farther/farthest)

name: As...As Comparisons
description: Use as + adjective + as for equality comparisons, and not as...as for inequality
examples: She is as tall as her brother
It's not as expensive as I thought
This is as good as that one

name: Too and Enough
description: Use too (excessive) before adjectives and enough (sufficient) after adjectives

name: Adverbs of Manner
description: Form and use adverbs ending in -ly to describe how actions are done

name: Quantifiers - Much, Many, A Lot Of
description: Use much with uncountable, many with countable, a lot of with both

name: Some and Any Usage
description: Use some in affirmatives and offers, any in negatives and questions

name: Countable vs Uncountable Nouns
description: Distinguish between countable (book/books) and uncountable nouns (water, information)

name: Something, Anything, Nothing
description: Use something/anything/nothing appropriately in different sentence types

name: One and Ones as Pronouns
description: Use one/ones to avoid repetition of countable nouns
examples: These shoes are nice, but those ones are better

name: Would Like for Polite Wants
description: Use would like (more polite than want) for desires and offers

name: Travel Vocabulary Set
description: Recognize and use travel-related vocabulary (airport, hotel, ticket, passport, luggage, flight, train, bus)
examples: I need to book a flight
The hotel is near the airport

name: Health and Body Vocabulary Set
description: Recognize and use health vocabulary (headache, stomach ache, fever, cold, flu, medicine, doctor, hospital)
examples: I need to see a doctor

name: Shopping Extended Vocabulary Set
description: Recognize and use shopping vocabulary (shop, store, size, price, expensive, cheap, sale, pay, receipt)

name: Hobbies and Sports Vocabulary Set
description: Recognize and use hobbies and sports vocabulary (swimming, running, cycling, dancing, painting, cooking, photography)

name: Transport Vocabulary Set
description: Recognize and use transport vocabulary (car, bus, train, plane, taxi, bicycle, motorcycle, subway)
examples: I go to work by bus

name: Weather Extended Vocabulary Set
description: Recognize and use extended weather vocabulary (cloudy, windy, foggy, snowy, storm, temperature, forecast)
examples: There will be a storm tomorrow

name: Describing People - Appearance
description: Describe physical appearance using adjectives (tall, short, slim, heavy, long hair, blonde, beard)

name: Describing People - Personality
description: Describe personality using adjectives (friendly, shy, funny, serious, kind, generous, lazy)
examples: My friend is kind and generous

name: Describing Places
description: Describe places using simple adjectives (beautiful, ugly, modern, old, clean, dirty, quiet, noisy)
examples: The beach is clean and quiet

name: Making Suggestions
description: Make suggestions using Let's, Why don't we, How about, Shall we

name: Agreeing and Disagreeing Simple
description: Express simple agreement (I agree, That's right, Me too) and disagreement (I don't agree, I don't think so)

name: Asking Permission A2
description: Ask for permission using Can I, Could I, May I

name: Inviting, Accepting, and Refusing
description: Make invitations and accept or refuse politely
examples: Would you like to come to dinner?

name: Making Phone Calls Basic
description: Make and answer phone calls with basic phrases (Hello, This is..., Can I speak to...?, Hold on)

name: Asking Directions Extended
description: Ask for and give more detailed directions (across from, next to, between, on the corner)
examples: It's between the post office and the park

name: At Restaurant - Ordering Extended
description: Order food with more detail, ask about dishes, make special requests
examples: Could I have water instead of soda?

name: Making Polite Complaints
description: Make simple polite complaints about problems (The room is too cold, This doesn't work, There's a problem)
examples: Excuse me, the room is too cold
There's a problem with my order

name: Talking About Feelings
description: Express feelings and emotions (happy, sad, angry, worried, excited, tired, bored)

name: Talking About Future Plans
description: Discuss future plans and intentions using going to and present continuous
examples: She's going to travel next month

name: Expressing Preferences
description: Express preferences using prefer, would rather, I'd rather
examples: She prefers reading to watching TV

name: Making Comparisons
description: Compare people, places, and things using comparative and superlative forms
examples: This book is better than that one
She is the tallest in the class

name: Telling Time Extended
description: Tell time using various forms including 24-hour clock and approximate times

name: Giving Simple Opinions
description: Express simple opinions using I think, In my opinion, I believe
examples: I think it's a good idea
In my opinion, the book is better

name: Sequencing Words
description: Use sequencing words to order events (first, then, next, after that, finally)
examples: First, I woke up. Then I had breakfast
Next, we went to the park. Finally, we went home

name: Writing Simple Emails
description: Write short informal emails with greetings, brief message, and closing
examples: Hi John, Thanks for your email. I'm fine. See you soon. Best, Maria

name: Writing Notes and Messages
description: Write short notes and messages for practical purposes (40-60 words)
examples: Dear John, I can't come to the meeting today. I'm sick. Sorry. See you tomorrow. Ana

name: Writing Short Paragraphs
description: Write simple connected paragraphs about familiar topics (80-120 words)
examples: My best friend is Ana. She is from Brazil. We met at university. She is very friendly and funny. We like to go to the cinema together

name: Writing Simple Descriptions
description: Describe people, places, or things in writing using simple sentences
examples: My house is big and modern. It has three bedrooms and a large garden. I love it

name: Writing About Past Events
description: Write about past experiences, trips, or events using past tenses
examples: Last summer I went to Spain. I visited Barcelona and Madrid. It was amazing. I loved the food

name: Writing About Future Plans
description: Write about future plans and intentions
examples: Next year I'm going to study abroad. I'm going to live in London and learn English

name: Pronunciation of -ed Endings
description: Pronounce -ed endings correctly as /t/, /d/, or /ɪd/

name: Weak Forms Basic
description: Recognize and produce weak forms of common words (can, to, and, of, for)

name: Contractions Expanded
description: Recognize and pronounce expanded set of contractions (I've, he's, they're, won't, wouldn't)

name: Word Stress Patterns
description: Identify and produce stress patterns in longer words (3+ syllables)

name: Connected Speech Basic
description: Recognize basic connected speech patterns (linking, assimilation)

name: Intonation in Lists
description: Use rising intonation for list items and falling on the last item
examples: I need bread↗, milk↗, eggs↗, and coffee↘

name: Reading - Identifying Main Ideas
description: Identify main ideas and key information in short simple texts

name: Reading - Basic Inference
description: Make simple inferences from context in predictable texts
examples: Why did she go to the doctor?

name: Reading - Prediction
description: Predict content from titles, pictures, and initial sentences
examples: Look at the title. What do you think the text is about?

name: Reading - Personal Letters and Emails
description: Understand personal correspondence about everyday matters
examples: Read and understand informal emails from friends

name: Listening - Specific Details
description: Understand specific details in short clear dialogues and announcements

name: Listening - Basic Inference
description: Make simple inferences about speakers' attitudes and feelings from tone

name: Listening - Everyday Conversations
description: Understand simple conversations on familiar everyday topics

name: Repair Strategies Initial
description: Use basic repair strategies (Sorry?, What?, Can you repeat?, I don't understand)

name: Circumlocution Minimal
description: Describe words you don't know using simple descriptions (It's a thing for..., It's like a...)
examples: It's a thing for cutting paper

name: Register Basic - Formal vs Informal
description: Recognize basic differences between formal and informal language
examples: Thanks vs Thank you very much

name: Fillers and Hesitation Devices
description: Use basic fillers while thinking (um, well, let me see, you know)

name: Checking Understanding
description: Check if others understand you (Do you understand?, Is that clear?, OK?)

name: Self-Correction A2
description: Notice and correct obvious errors in tenses, plurals, and word order

name: Pausing Appropriately
description: Pause at natural points in sentences for clarity
examples: Yesterday, [pause] I went to the park
My friend, [pause] who lives in London, [pause] is visiting
